Installer sees existing "Run with PowerShell 7" context menu entry and retains it after the update.


### Actual behavior

Installer removes context menu entry and installs the new version with default settings only (without context menu entry).

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user I want
* Intuitive module management, like Python or TypeScript
* Minimal overhead to creating modules

Currently, to create a module, you must export the members either by specifying them in your module manifest or using `Export-ModuleMember`.  The former is tedious for unpublished modules (modules only used for internal code reuse within a project) and the latter seems unintuitive to call a function to support a language construct.

I would like to declaratively specify which module members (at least functions) are exportable by applying a new `[Export]` attribute on the function.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As stated in the Stackoverflow answer [**Adding and Removing Xmlnode using**](https://stackoverflow.com/a/71092760/1701026), the PowerShell `Xml` dot referencing is a nice feature but is (to my opinion) a little overdone where it returns a `string` (rather than a `XmlElement`) in case it concerns a leaf node. This leads to inconsistency between the siblings and disconnects the object from the `xml` structure as noted in #11922 [**XML dot notation with indexed access doesn't work with assignments**](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/11922).
Without changing the actual `string` type (which would certainly be a break change), it could be considered *decorate* the string leaf with the same members (basically all methods) as the `XmlElement`.
For this, I have written a (quick & dirty) `Get-Node` function that adds the concerned methods and shows how this might help to overcome the current inconsistency (between a XmlElement and a String) and get back into the `xml` structure:

### `Get-Node`
<details>
  <summary>As PowerShell engine is able to change the xml node is either an XmlElement or String it is assumed that it should be able to decorate the string at the same moment.</summary>

```PowerShell
function Get-Node {
    [CmdletBinding()]Param (
        [String]$Name,
        [Parameter(ValueFromPipeLine = $True)][Xml.XmlElement]$Parent
    )
    process {
        $Nodes = $Parent.SelectNodes($Name)
        $Index = 0
        ForEach ($Child in $Parent.$Name) {
            if ($Child -is [String]) {
                $Child = $Child |Add-Member -MemberType NoteProperty -Name 'Node' -Value $Nodes[$index] -PassThru
                ForEach ($Name in $Nodes[$Index].PSObject.Methods.Name) {
                    If ($Child.PSObject.Methods.Name -NotContains $Name) {
                        $Method = [ScriptBlock]::Create("if (`$Args) { `$This.Node.$Name(`$Args) } else { `$This.Node.$Name() }")
                        $Child = $Child |Add-Member -MemberType ScriptMethod -Name $Name -Value $Method -PassThru
                    }
                }
            }
            $Child
            $Index++
        }
    }
}
```
</details>

```PowerShell
$Xml = [Xml]@'
<Lvl1>
  <Lvl2>a</Lvl2>
  <Lvl2>b</Lvl2>
  <Lvl2>  
    <Lvl3>1</Lvl3>
    <Lvl3>2</Lvl3>
  </Lvl2>
</Lvl1>
'@

$Lvl1Nodes = $Xml.Lvl1 |Get-Node('Lvl2') # For this, I would like use dot reference syntax: $Lvl1Nodes = $Xml.Lvl1.Lvl2
$Lvl1Nodes
a
b

Lvl3
----
{1, 2}
```

Note that e.g. the first `Lvl2` node is still a `string` that equals 'a':
```PowerShell
$Lvl1Nodes[0] -is [String]
True
$Lvl1Nodes[0] -eq 'a'
True
```

But now I am able to refer back into the `Xml` structure as concerned in #11922:
```PowerShell
$Lvl1Nodes[0].set_InnerText('Test')
[System.Xml.Linq.XDocument]::Parse($Xml.OuterXml).ToString()

<Lvl1>
  <Lvl2>Test</Lvl2>
  <Lvl2>b</Lvl2>
  <Lvl2>
    <Lvl3>1</Lvl3>
    <Lvl3>2</Lvl3>
  </Lvl2>
</Lvl1>
```

And the nodes act consistently (in e.g. selecting all of them to remove them from the parent):
```PowerShell
$Lvl1Nodes.SelectNodes('.').ForEach{ $Null = $_.ParentNode.RemoveChild($_) }
[System.Xml.Linq.XDocument]::Parse($Xml.OuterXml).ToString()

<Lvl1></Lvl1>
```

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16798
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3277
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/14146
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/7287
<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->
**Fixes the issue where namespaces would be removed from typenames with no regard for type name conflicts:**
```
using namespace System.Threading
using namespace System.Timers
[Timer<Tab>
```
Now it will tab complete to the shortest non ambiguous name, in this case it would just be the full name but if a namespace alias or "using system" had been defined it would use that instead. Note it won't fall back to type accelerators or type aliases even if they would have been shorter. IMO It would be confusing if the entered type name changed, for example "System.Sing<Tab>" turning info "float" and it would be annoying not being able to tab complete the real name if you for whatever reason wanted to use it.

**Fixes the issue where using statements in $profile had no effect on the tab completion.**  
This is done by first checking the script text for using statements and if none are found, fall back to the session state. The idea here is that if you are writing a script inside an editor the using statements there should have priority over whatever is in your session state.

**Fixes the issue where powershell defined types are only considered for tab completion if they are defined in the script text.**  
Now it will also include types from `using module` statements in the tab completion and types loaded into the session state.

**Adds the ability to find types/namespaces based on subnamespaces.**  
For example you can type in `Generic.List<Tab>` to tab complete to `System.Collections.Generic.List` instead of either having to type the full name, or just `list` and select it from a long list of names.

**Fixes the issue where quotes around using namespace statements aren't considered when removing the namespace from completion**, for example:
```
using namespace "System.Management"
[token<Tab>
```
currently completes to `[tomation.Language.Token]` instead of the proper [Automation.Language.Token]

**Limit the type completion suggestions to Attribute types when completing an attribute token**, for example:
```
[Parameter<Tab>(
# Results in 1 result "Parameter" because the "(" makes the parser see it as an attribute
[Parameter<Tab>
# Results in 22 results
```

**Increases and decreases the type completion performance a bit**
Using the following snippet to test: `Measure-Command { TabExpansion2 [s} | select Milliseconds`  
on fresh console launches it takes on average 177ms to complete. In my normal pwsh install it takes an average of 164.2ms.
Tab completing after the type cache has been built averages about 5,46ms with my new code and 9ms with my normal pwsh install. Interestingly there's a lot more variance in my code VS the old code. The old code sits consistently on 9ms while mine fluctuates between 4 and 6.  
These results make sense to me because my type cache does more work in advance and saves more data but maybe some C# genius can optimize it so it's always faster?

The code was designed and tested around the type/namespace alias support that is currently waiting to get reviewed and hopefully merged here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16734 the code specific to that change has been commented out, depending on what gets merged first it may need to get uncommented in a different PR.

On a side note, testing this code has made this PSReadline issue: https://github.com/PowerShell/PSReadLine/issues/722 much more apparent to me because there's so many completion items with the same ListItemText for example, tab completing `language` gets me `Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.Language` instead of my desired `System.Management.Automation.Language`. It should really look at the CompletionText instead, at least for types/namespaces since "apparent" duplicates are a lot more common here.

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

## PR Checklist

- [X] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes

    - If the PR is work in progress, please add the prefix `WIP:` or `[ WIP ]` to the beginning of the title (the `WIP` bot will keep its status check at `Pending` while the prefix is present) and remove the prefix when the PR is ready.

### Prerequisites

### Steps to reproduce

Using PowerShell 7.2.1 (I ran on Windows Server 2019 and on Debian 11.2 (4.4 kernel in Windows Subsystem for Linux)), enable tracing at level 1 or 2 and run this script (note that removing the `Custom` class's `Method` *prevents* the issue from occurring, but switching to `New-Object` *does not*):

```powershell
class Custom {
  [void] Method() {}
}

[Custom]::new()
```

title: When tracing, Language.PositionUtilities.BriefMessage() passes an out-of-range index to StringBuilder.Insert()

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

It would help a lot if Import-CSV could be told to ignore newlines within delimited fields. There are text fields which contain text which legitimately contains newlines.

Example of such legitimate use is output from some SQL server management tools found in www.firstresponderkit.org. It is really annoying that they can't be easily imported into Excel. And it does not help that Import-CSV can't handle it either.

The newlines for those tools are in columns which contain XML data. They work fine in SQL Server Management Studio, but getting the data into Excel would help a lot.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

title: Import-CSV importing fields with newlines

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I have complex in-house module that started to fail to import on recent daily builds of PS 7.3. It is working correctly on PS 5.1 and PS 7.2.1 and on older daily builds of PS 7.3. I was able to narrow the offending code to the following:
```powershell
Get-CimInstance -ClassName 'Win32_NetworkAdapterConfiguration' |
	Where-Object -Property IPEnabled |
	ForEach-Object {
		[IPAddress]::Parse(
			$_.IPSubnet[
				[Array]::IndexOf($_.IPAddress, $_.IPAddress[0])
			]
		)
	}
```

Error:
```powershell
ParserError: D:\Users\Bukem\Documents\PowerShell\SCRIPTS\Test.ps1:6
Line |
   6 |                  [Array]::IndexOf($_.IPAddress, $_.IPAddress[0])
     |                        ~
     | Missing ] at end of type token.

```

The *fix* is to enclose the ` [Array]::IndexOf($_.IPAddress, $_.IPAddress[0])` in extra pair of parentheses. Like so:
```powershell
Get-CimInstance -ClassName 'Win32_NetworkAdapterConfiguration' |
	Where-Object -Property IPEnabled |
	ForEach-Object {
		[IPAddress]::Parse(
			$_.IPSubnet[
				([Array]::IndexOf($_.IPAddress, $_.IPAddress[0]))
			]
		)
	}
```
But as I mentioned before the original code is working on PS 5.1, PS 7.2.1 and older daily builds of PS 7.3 so it has to be a recent change in the PS 7.3 code that is causing this.

### Expected behavior

```console
. .\Test.ps1

AddressFamily      : InterNetwork
ScopeId            :
IsIPv6Multicast    : False
IsIPv6LinkLocal    : False
IsIPv6SiteLocal    : False
IsIPv6Teredo       : False
IsIPv6UniqueLocal  : False
IsIPv4MappedToIPv6 : False
Address            : 16777215
IPAddressToString  : 255.255.255.0

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Powershell currently defaults to the console output encoding when running a native command. ([NativeCommandProcessor.cs:1330](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/186d6be47d858460a3d0ba6abd81f779cb633b55/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/NativeCommandProcessor.cs#L1330)). This is the right default for most programs, but some software chooses to output a different encoding instead (Most commonly UTF-8). e.g. Rust programs, or programs that use [`activeCodePage`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/sbscs/application-manifests#activeCodePage) in their manifest.

The problem is that there is no way to specify an alternate encoding using Powershell syntax. This leads to either having to temporarily change `[Console]::OutputEncoding`, or to run the process using the .NET `Process` class directly: [starship/src/init/starship.ps1:26-65](https://github.com/starship/starship/blob/e6a921b5b2a54ffd81368f9b3a573e49b5af1c9a/src/init/starship.ps1#L26-L65).

It would help if there was a builtin way to do this concisely.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Either a parameter to some cmdlet (`Start-Process`? Not sure if that one allows reading output, not to a file, though... ) that allows setting the `StandardOutputEncoding`). Or some new syntax for it, such as a special cast.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

`Format-Volume -DriveLetter New-VirtualDisk`

I made a typo for the drive letter argument and powershell instantly formatted without hesitation volumes: N,E,W,-,V,I,R,T,U,A,L,D,I,S,K

In this scenario, it should either prompt for confirmation to preventing catastrophe or error out on `-DriveLetter a_bunch_of_chars` while accepting -DriveLetter a,_,b,u,n,c... instead for char[].


Full Details:
https://www.reddit.com/r/DataHoarder/comments/snreoa/i_just_completely_wiped_all_my_most_important/

This guy summarized quite well what should actually happen and how to fix it:
https://www.reddit.com/r/DataHoarder/comments/snreoa/i_just_completely_wiped_all_my_most_important/hw8i9wm/

> > The description for the -DriveLetter parameter doesn't say anything about looping over char[], so it never should have been implemented that way.
> 
> It's implicitly mentioned by the fact that it takes a char array as input, instead of just a single char. IMO the documentation is fine, the real problem here is that they didn't implement ShouldProcess properly.  
> "Dangerous" commands in PowerShell are supposed to prompt for confirmation but clearly this command didn't. Looking at the module source under: "C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\Storage\Volume.cdxml" they did correctly remember to add this for that command:
> 
>     <Cmdlet>
>         <CmdletMetadata Verb="Format" ConfirmImpact="High" Aliases="Initialize-Volume" />
>         <Method MethodName="Format">
>     ...
> 
> They just forgot to add:
> 
>     <CmdletAdapterPrivateData>
> 	  <Data Name="ClientSideShouldProcess" />
>     </CmdletAdapterPrivateData>
> 
> to the class definition so it doesn't prompt like it should. If you add that it prompts as you would expect:
> 
>     PS C:\Windows\system32> Format-Volume -DriveLetter D,E
> 
>     Confirm
>     Are you sure you want to perform this action?
>     Performing the operation "Format" on target "MSFT_Volume (ObjectId = "{1}\\mycomputername\root/Microsoft/Windows/S...)".
>     [Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "Y"):
> 
>     Confirm
>     Are you sure you want to perform this action?
>     Performing the operation "Format" on target "MSFT_Volume (ObjectId = "{1}\\mycomputername\root/Microsoft/Windows/S...)".
>     [Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "Y"):
> 
> It's a shame Microsoft don't make all of their modules open source so issues like this can be fixed. Sure we can report the problem to Microsoft and wait for them to fix it, but for small issues like this it's more efficient with PRs.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Format-Volume -DriveLetter New-VirtualDisk


Confirm
Are you sure you want to perform this action?
Performing the operation "Format" on target "MSFT_Volume (ObjectId = "{1}\\mycomputername\root/Microsoft/Windows/S...)".
[Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "Y"):

Confirm
Are you sure you want to perform this action?
Performing the operation "Format" on target "MSFT_Volume (ObjectId = "{1}\\mycomputername\root/Microsoft/Windows/S...)".
[Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "Y"):
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

In PR [#10587](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/10587/files) the `Add-Type` cmdlet was changed to search for the `ref` directory under the directory of the executing assembly. This was done to support hosted PowerShell environments that were using the `Microsoft.PowerShell.SDK` NuGet.

In the AWS's Lambda (serverless) service this change doesn't work because the executing assembly is in a different directory then the provided PowerShell Lambda function. When users attempt to use the `Add-Type` cmdlet the ref assemblies are not found because the executing assembly is in `/var/runtime` but the PowerShell Lambda function along with the `ref` directory or extracting in the `/var/task` directory.   

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

If there was an environment variable like `PS_REF_DIRECTORY` that pointed to the ref directory our AWS tooling could ensure this environment variable would be set during deployment.

# PR Summary

This PR implements the Custom Remote Connections RFC:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-RFC/blob/master/Archive/Draft/RFC0063-Custom-Remote-Connections.md

## PR Context

These changes open up the internal PowerShell remoting API so that custom connections can be created as PowerShell modules.  This PR does not introduce any new functions, and instead selectively makes some previously internal APIs public so that third parties can create custom remote connections without modifying PowerShell core engine code.  See the above RFC for more details.

A new module repo has been created to serve as an example custom connection, by using the newly public API to create an SSH custom remote connection.
https://github.com/PaulHigin/SSHRemotingConnection

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I'm proceed Japanese text in PowerShell with range operator(..)

Generally, range operator used like as "a" .. "c".
```PowerShell
PS> "a".."c"
a
b
c
```
Therefore range operator can also be used Japanese Kanji.
```PowerShell
PS > "一".."七"
一
丁
丂
七
```
That characters Unicode code point is "一" to U+4E00, "七" to U+4E03 at CJK unified ideographs in Unicode 14.0.0 .
However, a bit Kanji and symbol (include Emoji) cannot represent by single char type. These are called surrogate pairs character.

Examples follow:
```PowerShell
PS> "`u{29E3D}"
𩸽
PS> "`u{1F600}"
😃
```

Then it is cannot cast string to char type.
```PowerShell
# Normal Kanji.
PS> [char]"`u{4E00}"
一
# Surrogate pairs character.
PS> [char]"`u{29e3d}"
InvalidArgument: Cannot convert value "𩸽" to type "System.Char". Error: "String must be exactly one character long."
😃
PS> [char]"`u{1F600}"
InvalidArgument: Cannot convert value "😀" to type "System.Char". Error: "String must be exactly one character long."

```
Please look at the page [Character encoding in .NET](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/base-types/character-encoding-introduction)

To excerpt from the page.
> However, for some languages and for some symbols and emoji, it takes two char instances to represent a single character. 

For that reason, I think that the range operator can only be using characters which can be cast to char type. But I think surrogate pairs characters should also be supported at the context of semantics.

Sorry for my bad english.



### Expected behavior

```console
PS> "一".."一"
一
PS> "`u{4E00}".."`u{4E00}"
一
PS> "𩸽".."𩸽"
𩸽
PS> "`u{29e3d}".."`u{29e3d}"
𩸽
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> "一".."一"
一
PS> "`u{4E00}".."`u{4E00}"
一
PS> "𩸽".."𩸽"
OperationStopped: Input string was not in a correct format.
PS> "`u{29e3d}".."`u{29e3d}"
OperationStopped: Input string was not in a correct format.
```


### Error details

```console
PS> Get-Error
Exception             :
    Type       : System.FormatException
    TargetSite :
        Name          : ThrowOverflowOrFormatException
        DeclaringType : System.Number, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=6.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e
        MemberType    : Method
        Module        : System.Private.CoreLib.dll
    Message    : Input string was not in a correct format.
    Data       : System.Collections.ListDictionaryInternal
    Source     : System.Private.CoreLib
    HResult    : -2146233033
    StackTrace :
   at System.Number.ThrowOverflowOrFormatException(ParsingStatus status, TypeCode type)
   at System.String.System.IConvertible.ToInt32(IFormatProvider provider)
   at System.Convert.ToInt32(Object value)
   at System.Management.Automation.ParserOps.RangeOperator(Object lval, Object rval)
   at System.Management.Automation.Interpreter.FuncCallInstruction`3.Run(InterpretedFrame frame)
   at System.Management.Automation.Interpreter.EnterTryCatchFinallyInstruction.Run(InterpretedFrame frame)
CategoryInfo          : OperationStopped: (:) [], FormatException
FullyQualifiedErrorId : System.FormatException
InvocationInfo        :
    ScriptLineNumber : 1

                       + ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    CommandOrigin    : Internal
ScriptStackTrace      : at <ScriptBlock>, <No file>: line 1

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a contributor to a Markdown wiki repo, I would like to be able to (cleanly) parse [YAML frontmatter](https://pandoc.org/MANUAL.html#extension-yaml_metadata_block) blocks in PowerShell via `ConvertFrom-Markdown`.

While there's a workaround available by manually extracting the HeaderBlock from parsed tokens and feeding its inline content to a YAML parser, this is very counterintuitive. Moreover, YAML frontmatter is rendered to HTML in the generated document, which isn't ideal either. (Normally, Markdig suppresses HTML generation for these tokens).



### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

This is already a native feature of Markdig, so it should be as easy as calling [`.UseYamlFrontMatter()`](https://atashbahar.com/post/2020-06-16-extract-front-matter-in-dotnet-with-markdig) on `MarkdownPipelineBuilder` before `.Build()`.

Given that these are essentially document properties, a property added to `[Microsoft.PowerShell.MarkdownRender.MarkdownInfo]` instances that extracts YAML frontmatter (if present) and deserializes to a CLR object would likely be the most sensible to use.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Consider the following pattern, common among PowerShell libraries, including official Microsoft ones such as [Azure-PowerShell](https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/search?q=%24PSCmdlet.ParameterSetName):
```ps1
function Foo {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param(
        [Parameter(ParametersetName="First")]
        [switch] $A,
        [Parameter(ParametersetName="Second")]
        [switch] $B,
        [Parameter(ParametersetName="Third")]
        [switch] $C
    )

    switch ($PSCmdlet.ParameterSetName) {
        "First" { Write-Host "First set selected" }
        "Second" { Write-Host "Second set selected" }
        "Third" { Write-Host "Third set selected" }
    }
}
```

Straightforward executions work well:
`Foo -A` -> _First set selected_
`Foo -B` -> _Second set selected_
`Foo -C` -> _Third set selected_

However, any attempt to explicitly set switch parameter values using a boolean value (which is invaluable in scripting) will fail:
`Foo -A:$true -b:$false` -> _**Parameter set cannot be resolved using the specified named parameters. One or more parameters issued cannot be used together or an insufficient number of parameters were provided.**_

Of course, this breaks the Switch parameter contract when specified as above: https://github.com/Azure/azure-powershell/issues/12881





### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

There seem to be many suggestions for improving the parameter set experience (https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/11237, https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13746, https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10137, https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/12818 etc.) however many of them have far reaching, backward compatibility implications. 

There is one suggestion in particular I think could be very helpful, namely an additional attribute value to help PowerShell's resolution mechanism choose the right parameter set by considering the parameter's value, not just its presence (in this case `$false` would not match the selector)
* https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/4102 (see my comment there as well).

# PR Summary
fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/8873
This will make trailing commas allowed in most scenarios:
```
param ($x,$y,)
[ValidateSet("X","Y",)]$x
"hello".Split('h','e',)
```
In all 3 cases, commas have also been made optional as long as the new argument isn't on the same line as the old one:
```
param (
    $x

    $y
)

[ValidateSet(
    "X"
    "Y"
)]$x

"hello".Split(
    'h'
    'e'
)
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. install an older version of PowerShell, e.g. [release 7.1.5](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.1.5).
a. Choose a unique path, e.g. `C:\PowerShell\7.1.5` (which installs to `C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7`).
b. Installer _PowerShell 7-x64 Setup_ settings (though these should not affect this bug occurring)
☑Add PowerShell to Path Environment Variable
☑Register Windows Event Logging Manifest
☑Enable PowerShell remoting
c. Note the contents of the installation path (default `C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7`) has the installation files, i.e. the following command will run `C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7\pwsh.exe`.
2. install a newer version of PowerShell, e.g. [release 7.2.1](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.2.1)
a. Choose a unique path, e.g. `C:\PowerShell\7.2.1` (which installs to `C:\PowerShell\7.2.1\7`).
b. Installer _PowerShell 7-x64 Setup_ settings (though these should not affect this bug occurring)
☑Add PowerShell to Path Environment Variable
☑Register Windows Event Logging Manifest
☑Enable PowerShell remoting
3. run the old version, i.e. command `C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7\pwsh.exe`.
The command fails with:
`C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7\pwsh.exe: The term 'C:\PowerShell\7.1.5\7\pwsh.exe' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.`
The old PowerShell installation was unexpectedly removed.

This can be reproduced in a Windows Sandbox instance.

### Expected behavior

```console
PowerShell installer should either:
- ask the User installing if they would like to remove prior PowerShell installations (if "yes" then specify which ones)
- just not remove prior PowerShell installations

System-wide unique settings, i.e. settings that can only point to one instance of PowerShell, e.g. _Enable PowerShell remoting_, should be overwritten by the last run PowerShell installer.

Some Windows users may want multiple PowerShell installations side-by-side.
Especially developers testing PowerShell scripts on multiple versions of PowerShell.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Prior PowerShell installations are removed despite not being requested by the user.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\PowerShell\7.2.1\7> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19041
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
```


### Visuals

_No response_

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

It would be great to have more control over the results from the Select-String cmdlet.  

One use case would be to colorize the Path that is shown. Presently - the matched value is emphasized, which is great. However, if there are long paths in the results - then it can be difficult to separate the Path from the Line that displays in the output.

It would be nice to customize the color of the Emphasis, as well. 

It seems like leveraging PSStyle would be a great way to put this into action, similar to how the FileInfo options are used.

title: Suggestion: PSStyle usage for MatchInfo object

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I'm keen on #8873, but why stop at method calls and param blocks?

Python allows this syntax:

``` python
list = [
    'foo',
    'bar',
]
```

The trailing comma after `'bar'` is what I would like to see in PowerShell.

The advantages are:

- appending to a list is a one-line diff, not a 2-line diff
- commenting out the last list entry is not a syntax error

I would like all bracket-enclosed list expressions to support this:

``` powershell
$List = (
   'foo',
   'bar',
)

$List = @(
   'foo',
   'bar',
)
```

I do NOT propose support without the brackets, because it seems like a serious breaking change:

``` powershell
# This should remain a syntax error
$List = 'foo', bar',
$a = 123
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

See more detail at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/62943

In short words: PowerShell can list the existence of such file, but not manipulating it.
Such file is unsupported in many cases (including Windows explorer and notepad). Supporting in PowerShell makes manipulating it easier.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

The linked .NET issue gives a solution, and explained why they don't want to enable it at their side.

Most (if not all) of the built-in PowerShell Cmdlets that accept the [Common Parameters](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_commonparameters?view=powershell-7.2), should respond to the `-Verbose` parameter by outputting some informational message about the cmdlet's invocation to the console.

The `Set-Alias` cmdlet of the same `Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility` source, responds to the -Verbose option as expected, so it follows that the `Remove-Alias` cmdlet as part of the general 'alias interaction' category of cmdlets, should as well.

```powershell
Function Dumby-Func { echo 'testing' }

PS> Set-Alias -Name dumbfun -Value Dumby-Func -Verbose
#--> VERBOSE: Performing the operation "Set Alias" on target "Name: dfun Value: Dummy-Func".

PS> dumbfun
#--> testing

PS> Remove-Alias -Name dumbfun -Verbose
#< No Output >
```

### Expected behavior

```console
PS> Remove-Alias MyAlias -Verbose
VERBOSE: Performing the operation "Remove Alias" on target "Name: MyAlias".
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Remove-Alias MyAlias -Verbose
< No Output >
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a script developer I would like to use statements such as `switch` at the beginning of a pipeline, e. g.:
~~~powershell
# Wishful thinking

switch -File 'input.txt' { 
    '--start--'  { $include = $true } 
    { $include } { $_ }   # Output included line
    '--end--'    { $include = $false }
} | Set-Content 'output.txt'
~~~

This would allow me to use the output of such a statement in a _streaming_ fashion, without having to collect all output into a variable first.

Unfortunately this produces a **ParserError**:
~~~
Line |
   5 |  } | Set-Content 'output.txt'        
     |    ~
     | An empty pipe element is not allowed.
~~~

Currently I have to resort to this **workaround**, which wraps the statement in a **scriptblock**:
~~~powershell
# Workaround

& { switch -File 'input.txt' { 
    '--start--'  { $include = $true } 
    { $include } { $_ }   # Output included line
    '--end--'    { $include = $false }
}} | Set-Content 'output.txt'
~~~

While this works, it is not as clean as it could be. Inexperienced users stumbling upon such code have to learn about call operator and script blocks first, before understanding the code.
 
There is also some inconsistency compared to commands and expressions. While the output of a statement can be captured in a variable, it cannot be used _directly_ in a pipeline. Commands and expressions on the other hand have both abilities.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Run the following code:

```
Set-StrictMode -version latest

[string] $content = @"
[
  {
    "First": "1"
  },
  {
    "Second": "2"
  }
]
"@

$json = (ConvertFrom-Json -InputObject $content)
$json.Second
```

### Expected behavior

```console
To get `2`.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
An error that says `The property 'Second' cannot be found on this object. Verify that the property exists.`
```


### Error details

```console
This issue was exhibiting itself in the context of a much larger script and it took me a while to narrow it down to Strict Mode... 

Inspecting the issue, I discovered that setting the Strict Mode to lower than 2 causes the issue to stop appearing and the input text to get parsed correctly.

Could not find any documentation about ConvertFrom-Json changing behavior in respect to Strict Mode, so I am guessing that this is a bug.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell 7.2.1 on Windows 11 Professional x64.

As a note, the issue also is also reproducible on Windows PowerShell.
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Importing the newer version of the Teams Online PowerShell module takes a long time.

PS> Measure-Command {Import-Module microsoftteams -RequiredVersion 3.1.0}
gives results from 15 to 35 seconds in my systems (PS7.2.1, but also tested on PS5.1)

The culprit is a section of this file:
**3.1.0\net472\Microsoft.Teams.ConfigAPI.Cmdlets.psm1**:
```
  if($exportsPath) {
    Get-ChildItem -Path $exportsPath -Recurse -Include '*.ps1' -File | ForEach-Object { . $_.FullName }
    $cmdletNames = Get-ScriptCmdlet -ScriptFolder $exportsPath
    #Export-ModuleMember -Function $cmdletNames -Alias (Get-ScriptCmdlet -ScriptFolder $exportsPath -AsAlias)      
  }

```
PowerShell has to dot load each individual export file (700) and verify its signature.
On my test systems, this section takes from 14 to 30 seconds the first time I load the module in a new shell.

By combining the export files into a single file, stripping the signatures from the file, and dot-loading that single file, I could import the whole module in less than 5 seconds.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

I suggest that before release, you have the build process merge the export files into 1 file, and sign it, as that should significantly speed up whenever importing the module in a new shell.

labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

# PR Summary

We needed to invoke pwsh to generate the list of experimental features. Hence, it did not work on cross compiled packages like ARM and Alpine. Now we have static file with the experimental feature list. This is used as the source of truth for listing the experimental feature to be included in the powershell.config.json.

Updated build configurations to use the experimental files json.

# PR Summary

Fix #16809
Follow up on #12412

Add a couple fixes to generic method invocation:
1. For a generic type argument, if it doesn't exist at compilation time but available at run time, it should work as expected.
2. For a generic type argument, if it doesn't exist at all, we should report error about which type name cannot be resolved.
3. Make sure the tests actually run and fix all the tests.

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

pwsh.exe 7.2.1 is consistently crashing in terminal when using the alternant screen buffer ansi commands. It appears to not be able to read the console buffer after a return to the original screen (ESC[?1049l). 

This issue appears to not happen in 7.1.4, but does happen in 7.2.1.

Code to reproduce:
>
>   $ESC = [char]27
>    for($i=0; $i -lt 100; $i++) {
>        $host.ui.Write("$ESC[?1049h")
>        $host.ui.Write("Alternate screen buffer")
>        $host.ui.Write("$ESC[?1049l")
>        $host.ui.Write('.')
>    }



### Expected behavior

```console
Not having the pwsh application crash.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
[process exited with code 2148734499]
```


### Error details

```console
Since the process terminates it is impossible to use Get-Error however these are the event logs generated.

`Faulting application name: pwsh.exe, version: 7.2.1.500, time stamp: 0x61735063

Faulting package full name: Microsoft.PowerShell_7.2.1.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe
Faulting package-relative application ID: App`

`Application: pwsh.exe
CoreCLR Version: 6.0.21.52210
.NET Version: 6.0.0
Description: The application requested process termination through System.Environment.FailFast(string message).
Message: The Win32 internal error "No process is on the other end of the pipe." 0xE9 occurred while getting console output buffer information. Contact Microsoft Customer Support Services.
Description: The process was terminated due to an unhandled exception.System.Management.Automation.Host.HostException: The Win32 internal error "No process is on the other end of the pipe." 0xE9 occurred while getting console output buffer information. Contact Microsoft Customer Support Services.
 ---> System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception (233): No process is on the other end of the pipe.

I want this entire PowerShell Docs site as a downloadable (and printable - aka ring binder, take it to Staples and get it bound, etc) so I can have it as a desk reference. ### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

### Steps to reproduce

Where-Object produces incorrect and inconsistent results depending on whether a scriptblock or property is used for the criteria

I found this issue with much more complicated function I wrote BUT have reduced it down the following example code:

        $o = [pscustomobject] @{ Value1 = 'abc' ; Value2 = 'abc' }

        $o

             which displays the following ( as expected )

                      Value1 Value2
                      ------ ------
                      abc    abc

        $o.Value1 -eq $o.Value2

              which returns True ( as expected )

        $o | Where-Object Value1 -ne Value2

              which returns the following which is NOT expected

                    Value1 Value2
                    ------ ------
                    abc    abc

        $o | Where-Object { $_.Value1 -ne $_.Value2 }

                which returns NOTHING as expected since Value1 and Value2 are the same

Why does "$o | Where-Object Value1 -ne Value2" produce the wrong result and not the same result as 
"$o | Where-Object { $_.Value1 -ne $_.Value2 }"

I thought the purpose of simple Where-Object use was to avoid the script block?

What have I missed ?

```console
Documented inline with example
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Documented inline with example
```

body:
This is a follow-up issue to https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/12412
Ideally, member group for method with generic arguments should show "OverloadDefinitions" with the specified argument types applied.

Repro steps:
```
PS> $linq = [System.Linq.Enumerable]
PS> $linq::Distinct[int]

OverloadDefinitions
-------------------
static System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable[TSource] Distinct[TSource](System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable[TSource] source)
static System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable[TSource] Distinct[TSource](System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable[TSource] source,
System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer[TSource] comparer)
```
The generic arguments are parsed and the `ITypeName` are kept in `MemberExpressionAst`, but it's not used when generating the overload definition.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

`Get-ItemPropertyValue` automatically expand `REG_EXPAND_SZ` value when fetching one from the windows registry.
With this behavior, the coder cannot read a value, modify it, and write it back to the registry. It is a problem since juste READING a value actually MODIFY the value.

I would suggest to add an option to just read the value as-is. For example `-Raw` to get it simple. Or if you want a `-Options` with an object of type `RegistryValueOptions`.

I would prefer a simple `-Raw` option (like in `Get-Content -Raw`) to be used like this :
`Get-ItemPropertyValue -Path "HKLM:\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Session Manager\Environment" -Name "Path" -Raw`


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

This post https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51776242/how-to-retrieve-original-unresolved-unexpanded-registry-value give a workaround : 
```
(Get-Item -Path HKCU:\Environment).GetValue(
  'PATH',  # the registry-value name
  $null,   # the default value to return if no such value exists.
  'DoNotExpandEnvironmentNames' # the option that suppresses expansion
)
```
But it is far way more complicated and unintuitive in comparison of just `Get-ItemPropertyValue -Path HKCU:\Environment -Name PATH -Raw` (I think).

Thank you

title: Error report is wrong when the generic argument of a generic type cannot be resolved

body:
Use this issue to track my review comment https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/12412#discussion_r793031059 regarding `PSMethodInvocationConstraints.GenericTypeParameters`.

There are 2 problems with invocation of method with generic arguments today:
1. For `$a.MethodName[type-A]($arg)`, if `[type-A]` cannot be resolved at all, there is no good error message on what type name cannot be resolved.
2. For `$a.MethodName[type-A]($arg)`, if `[type-A]` can be resolved at run time (new assembly gets loaded or so), it won't be honored, because we only attempt to resolve the type at compilation time in compiler.

It's not a problem for `PSMethodInvocationConstraints.ParameterTypes`, because for any argument conversion, if we cannot resolve the type when constructing `PSMethodInvocationConstrains` (namely, the element in `ParameterTypes` is `null`), then we will just use the [effective argument type](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/CoreAdapter.cs#L1427) in `FindBestMethodImpl`.

The fix would be to refactor `PSMethodInvocationConstraints.GenericTypeParameters` somewhat, to allow a compile-time unresolvable type to fall back to [TypeOps.ResolveTypeName](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/runtime/Operations/MiscOps.cs#L2116) in `FindBestMethodImpl`. That method will take care of the type loaded at run time, as well as generating better error message when a type name really cannot be resolved.

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

labels.description: core PowerShell engine, interpreter, and runtime
labels.name: WG-Engine

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Refactor `PSMethodInvocationConstraints` to make it able to work with types that not available at compilation time but loaded at runtime

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

The [**SecureString operations**](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.security.securestring?view=net-6.0#securestring-operations) warning:

> ⚠ Important
>
> A SecureString object should never be constructed from a String, because the sensitive data is already subject to the memory persistence consequences of the immutable String class. The best way to construct a SecureString object is from a character-at-a-time unmanaged source, such as the Console.ReadKey method.

Also implies that a SecureString object should never be constructed from a ***clipboard* string**.
Therefore `Read-Host -AsSecureString` should not allow to for clipboard pasting (or have at least have a switch for this*)

* e.g. `-AllowClipboardPaste`, meaning that I recommend to disallow by default
This will make developers aware of this security risk.
* In "disallow" mode, an additional `Write-Warning` to the user might be given that placing passwords on the clipboard is a potential security risk.

Related (contradicted) issue: [`#3511` Read-Host -AsSecureString failing on pasting value into it](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3511)

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Issue copied from https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs/issues/8505

Due to the addition of `ResolvedTarget` in issue https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13366 and PR https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16490, and the lack of any mention of PowerShell on the C# page for [`FileInfo`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-US/dotnet/api/System.IO.FileInfo?view=net-6.0) and [`DirectoryInfo`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-US/dotnet/api/System.IO.DirectoryInfo?view=net-6.0), it may make sense to create a separate page for these objects in the PowerShell documentation, so they may have the aforementioned `ResolvedTarget` property, which doesn't exist outside of PowerShell.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

.NET API documentation must be updated in the PowerShell source code.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I've looked into the type completion and have come up with this list of issues:

1: It doesn't take conflicting `Using namespace` statements into consideration, for example:
```
using namespace System.Threading
using namespace System.Timers
[Timer<Tab>
```
will suggest "Timer" but if you actually tried to use that you would get a runtime error due to the ambiguous type (it's either System.Threading.Timer or System.Timers.Timer). Ideally it would find the shortest unambiguous name, which in this case would be Threading.Timer and Timers.Timer due to the implicit System namespace.

2: PowerShell types and Using namespace statements are only taken into consideration if they are included in the script text that is being completed. To demonstrate, you can add an Enum and a using statement to your $profile:
```
using namespace System.Collections.Generic
enum Whatever
{
    value1 = 1
}
```
From a new console, If you try to complete `Whatever` in the console you'll get no results. If you try to complete `List` it will suggest `System.Collections.Generic.List` instead of just `List`.  
Ideally PowerShell types defined in the script text as well as ones that have been loaded into the session should be included in the completions. For using statements, it should use the ones in the script text and if there aren't any, fall back to the ones loaded into the session.

3: PowerShell types imported through using module aren't considered for completion. Fixing the previous issue would partially fix this, but maybe it's also worth parsing the specified module? The Symbol resolver code does this at parse time so maybe the completion code should as well?

4: Namespaces aren't taken into consideration when completing input, their only use seems to be to trim types that are found. For example:
```
using namespace System.Collections
[Generic.List<Tab>
#or
[Generic.<Tab>
```

won't complete to anything. You have to type the full name to get any completions.

5: Quotes aren't handled properly in the namespace removal in the completion if used in `using namespace`
For example:
```
using namespace "System.Management"
[token<Tab>
```
completes to `[tomation.Language.Token]` instead of `[Automation.Language.Token]`
### Expected behavior

```console
N/A
```


### Actual behavior

```console
N/A
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\Users\Martin> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0-preview.10
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0-preview.10
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1

```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Hello

### The issue
in our daily work (we've created more than 5k PowerShell Scrips) we mostly have runtime errors because functions do not initialize variables in all code-paths and then the value of the parent (or even global!) variable with the same name is used.

### Therefore: Please allow us to disable variable inheritance for functions

#### The benefit of inherited variables in functions
Professional scripts almost never want to access global variables in functions
If they do:
- it is very rare
- they usually need single variables, which can then be explicitly addressed in the function

#### The Workarounds
I know, there are workarounds to manually disable inheritance in functions, e.g. by creating a local variable of every global variable and initializing them to $null. Or by creating a new PowerShell process. Or by using ScriptBlocks, Jobs, etc.
In the end, however, they are all very tedious.

I have added some ideas for the technical implementation below.

Thanks a lot, kind regards,
Thomas

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

### Ideas for discussion
As always, it's tricky to choose an elegant, sustainable concept for such requirements - and PowerShell has great architects, thank goodness. I'll give a few concept ideas anyway:

Variable inheritance into Functions could be disabled by:
- a `#Command` similar to: `#Requires -Version 7`
- by the `private:` scope like: `Function private:My-Func() {} `

### By the way, the implementation of this requirement should be quite simple:

As soon as a variable is accessed in a function for the 1st time, 
PowerShell does not copy the value from an existing parent
but simply initializes it by the default value.

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: core PowerShell engine, interpreter, and runtime
labels.name: WG-Engine

title: Please allow to disable Variable inheritance for Functions

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a PowerShell user for several users, I didn't realize until recently that you can select a row in Out-GridView and hit Ctrl+C to copy the row's contents. My intuition told me to try and right click to see if there was a menu item with an entry labeled `Copy (Ctrl+C)` like in most applications, but there never was so I never knew. It'd be nice if you could:

1. Right click and have a context menu popup showing an entry for `Copy (Ctrl+C)`

# PR Summary

The progress rendering code hides the cursor during rendering and makes the cursor visible again after rendering as it assumes the cursor was previously in a visible state.  However, if a script intentionally hides the cursor, then using progress will result in the cursor being visible.  However, it seems that only Windows supports reading the current cursor visibility state and a platform not supported exception is thrown on Linux and macOS.  So the fix is to just cache the current cursor on Windows and set it back when done rendering.  No change for Linux/macOS as we still want to explicitly hide the cursor when rendering progress so that you don't see the cursor moving quickly in the console to render progress.

## PR Context

Fix #16412

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I can create a computer restore point in PowerSHell 7.2.1. 

```powershell
Checkpoint-Computer -description "pre winget updates"
Get-ComputerRestorePoint
```

But getting the restore point doesn't show the creation time. The value is there in the object as a DMTF string. But it doesn't get formatted. This works as expected in Windows PowerShell.

### Expected behavior

```console
PS C:\> Get-ComputerRestorePoint

CreationTime           Description                    SequenceNumber    EventType         RestorePointType
------------           -----------                    --------------    ---------         ----------------
1/20/2022 2:11:26 PM   Pre winget updates             63                BEGIN_SYSTEM_CHA… APPLICATION_INSTALL
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS C:\> Get-ComputerRestorePoint

CreationTime           Description                    SequenceNumber    EventType         RestorePointType
------------           -----------                    --------------    ---------         ----------------
                       Pre winget updates             63                BEGIN_SYSTEM_CHA… APPLICATION_INSTALL
```


### Error details

```console
There are no errors.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\> $PSVersionTable 

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12089920/150407520-473be104-7406-4324-8f0f-6c207986a46e.png)

This works in Windows PowerShell on Windows 11 with no problem.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12089920/150407818-9605fbf8-0ca8-4588-a9e1-a9fb844016d9.png)

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

This is a follow-up issue to https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15429 which has been closed. The Cmdet working group has agreed that a new cmdlet called `Get-TranscriptStatus` should be developed.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

The cmdlet should be scope and user-specific only. It should indicate if transcription is currently running and to what file. For security purposes the cmdlet should only return information for the current user.
